‚ÄúWhen you empower people, they don‚Äôt just change their lives, they transform their communities.‚Äù üôå 

In Mugae, Kenya, what once required a five-hour trek for a single jerry can of water is now just a short walk away. For years, women carried 20-litre cans across harsh terrain, but today, life looks very different.

üö∞ Through the work of Food for the Hungry Kenya, the Mugae Maji ya Chumvi borehole was restored with solar power, strong fencing, and sustainable systems that protect this vital water source. 

üéâ But the true story of transformation belongs to the people of Mugae themselves. They formed a Borehole Management Committee, elected their own leaders, and now manage the water system with care and vision.

üå≥ They are planting trees, cultivating green spaces, and even planning a fishpond to create new sources of income. Clean water is no longer just about survival, it‚Äôs about opportunity and dignity.

This progress is possible because of kind people like you who believe in empowering communities to lead their own change. Together, we‚Äôre helping bring water, and hope, closer to home.

‚ÄúOnce I spent half my day searching for water. Now, I go to school on time, study without exhaustion, and I dream of becoming a nurse. This water has changed everything in my community.‚Äù 
‚Äî Yvette, age 10, Rwanda üíö

In Saruheshyi Cell, clean water was once only a dream. Families walked hours each day to collect water from unsafe sources, and children often missed school. Today, more than 1,000 people have access to safe, reliable water right in their community.

This transformation was made possible by the leadership of local residents and partners who built and now maintain the system themselves. 

Clean water doesn‚Äôt just fill cups. It fuels education, strengthens health, and restores dignity so that every person can live the life God intended and build a legacy that transforms generations.

‚ÄúMy family is not as sick as before because we live with good hygiene. I have the courage from Food for the Hungry staff to share with others, even though I cannot read,‚Äù says Lach Lin. üíö

Before Food for the Hungry entered her community in Cambodia, Lach Lin‚Äôs family struggled with many water-related illnesses. ‚ÄúWe used to drink from a water tank that did not have a lid and the water did not boil properly, causing family members to experience diarrhea, typhoid fever, and abdominal pain,‚Äù she recalls.

Thanks to kind supporters like you, Lach Lin and her family now have access to clean water, chickens to raise, and seeds to grow healthy vegetables. These life-changing resources have helped her family live healthier lives and build a brighter future. üíß

Through your support, families like Lach Lin‚Äôs are thriving physically and emotionally, equipped with the tools they need to grow and share hope with others. ü´∂üèº

Will you let a child drink dirty water‚Äîor turn on the tap?  üíß

If you‚Äôre a child like Edna in Mozambique, you have no choice but to drink dirty, disease-ridden water. And it‚Äôs a price no child should have to pay.  

üìçAccording to the World Health Organization, some 1,000 children under the age of 5 die each day because of unsafe water and sanitation. 

That‚Äôs 40 kindergarten classes of children just disappearing from planet earth ‚Äî into eternity ‚Äî because the water they drink kills them rather than quenches their thirst. 

Every day without clean water puts Edna‚Äôs life and future at risk.

üí¨ ‚ÄúI am truly pleased to have access to clean and separate restrooms for boys, girls, and individuals with disabilities, along with a designated area for girls' menstrual hygiene.‚Äù ‚Äî Sreylan, 6th-grade student

For the girls of Rolum Touk, school used to be a place of discomfort ‚Äî not because they didn‚Äôt want to learn, but because it lacked the most basic essentials: safe toilets, clean water, and dignity.

Without proper hygiene facilities, many girls stayed home during their periods. With no handwashing stations or drinking water, sickness was common, and attendance was inconsistent. Learning was not always the top priority.

But that changed when the community, alongside Food for the Hungry Cambodia, took action.

üíô An inclusive latrine was built, with private spaces for girls
üö∞ Clean water filters were installed
üñê Hygiene education became a part of daily school life
üìö The library was stocked with storybooks to inspire imagination
üë©‚Äçüè´ Teachers were trained to support students' physical and emotional health

Today, girls no longer worry about where they‚Äôll go to the bathroom or whether they‚Äôll have safe, fresh water to drink. They walk into class with confidence, wash their hands before meals, and focus fully on what matters most: their education.

When basic needs are met, children ‚Äî especially girls ‚Äî can dream, learn, and thrive. 

#FoodfortheHungry #LetGirlsLearn #WASHinSchools #FHImpact #Cambodia #EducationForAll #ChildSponsorship #DignityFirst #WaterChangesEverything

The Spinning Top: A Game That Shaped Generations

In the dusty streets of Peru and across Latin America, children gather with one simple toy üåÄ the spinning top üåÄ a wooden game full of challenge, laughter, and tradition.

With a flick of the wrist and a swirl of string, the top spins into action. The goal? Make it "fall asleep," dance in your palm, or spin the longest. Each trick takes practice and patience.

More than a game, the spinning top builds confidence, creativity, and community ‚Äî values that shape young lives for the better.

text:
You helped Mother Janet triple her harvest‚Äîthank you!

Mother-of-five Janet works hard as a small-scale farmer in Uganda. For years, she struggled to make her rocky, hilly land produce enough to feed her family.  

‚ÄúIt used to be hectic and tiresome,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd spend hours and money on chemicals, but little was harvested.‚Äù 

Then someone generous like you decided to sponsor one of Janet‚Äôs children. That opened the door for Janet to join farming training, where she learned new practices, like rotating her crops and using organic fertilizer.

Now her bean harvest has tripled! She‚Äôs growing maize, potatoes, bananas, and eggplant to feed her children, with extra to sell. For the first time, she can save money each week instead of spending it on expensive fertilizers.

‚ÄúBecause of what I‚Äôve learned, my family is eating better, our income is growing, and I can look to the future with hope,‚Äù says Janet. 

Thank you for helping families like Janet‚Äôs flourish‚Äîphysically, emotionally, and spiritually. Your generosity is planting seeds of hope and changing lives!

text:
What‚Äôs your favorite fall drink? 

In the U.S., nothing says fall like wrapping your hands around a warm cup of apple cider blended with cinnamon spice for cozy comfort. üçé

Did you know children in Bolivia enjoy their own version of this warm and cinnamon-y drink? It‚Äôs called Api, meaning ‚Äúporridge‚Äù or ‚Äúthick drink,‚Äù made from purple corn kernels, plus ground yellow corn, sugar, cinnamon sticks, and cloves for extra flavor.

You‚Äôll smell cinnamon-rich Api simmering away in the Bolivian highlands, greeting travelers at bus terminals, and keeping families warm as they celebrate at carnivals.

Like apple cider for us Americans in fall, Api brings comfort and joy to many children and families in Bolivia. 

Wherever we live, harvest-time drinks can warm our bodies and hearts‚Äîand remind us to thank God for what He so lovingly puts in our hands.

text:
A glimpse of what your sponsored child's life is like in Bangladesh: 

üíö Houses are commonly rectangular and made out of mud, bamboo, or red brick with thatched roofs. Many are built on platforms to keep them above the flood line.

üíö Many meals are cooked in spicy curry sauces that incorporate cumin, coriander, cloves, cinnamon, garlic, and other spices.

üíö Primary education, which is free but not required by law, is for children 10 and under. Only about half of all children in Bangladesh attend primary school.

üíö People greet each other with, ‚ÄúAssalam Waleykum‚Äù (peace be with you) and respond with, ‚ÄúWaleykum Assalam‚Äù (and with you).

üå± ‚ÄúThere are a lot of people who go to me and say, ‚ÄòSir Pat, what are you doing differently from us? We experienced the same tragedy. Why is your life different now?‚Äô‚Äù ‚Äî Paterno Padua, Founder, La Cocina de Marabut

In just six years, Paterno went from surviving Super Typhoon Yolanda to founding a restaurant, farm school, and cooperative organic farm that now empowers his entire community.

His secret?

Strict organization. Commitment. And climate-smart farming training from Food for the Hungry.

We‚Äôre proud to be featured by TriplePundit for supporting this extraordinary journey of resilience and innovation.

üì∞ Read more about Sir Pat‚Äôs story: https://triplepundit.com/2025/philippines-climate-adapatation-farming/

 #ClimateAdaptation #FoodForTheHungry #ClimateResilience #DisasterRecovery #Philippines #TriplePundit #SustainableFarming #OrganicAgriculture #LaCocinaDeMarabut

text:
üíöüíöüíö "I Didn‚Äôt Know How. Now I Do."

Runa used to think school was enough. But through Food for the Hungry's Education Cascade Program, she learned what every child really needs to thrive - love, structure, care, and encouragement.

Now, not only is she sending her daughter Maysa to school, she‚Äôs helping other moms do the same. üìö

From adult literacy to mother leader, Runa is proof that when a woman learns, a generation rises.

üëâ This is how we break the cycle. One mom. One child. One future at a time.

media.ocrText: May be an image of 1 person

text:
Meet Maria from Guatemala! 
She is a hardworking mother, entrepreneur, and dreamer. For many years, Food for the Hungry has been walking alongside her community with programs in education, health, and agriculture.

Through Food for the Hungry-led training, Maria gained the knowledge and confidence to start her own tortilla business, providing for her family while caring for her young son.

"Before, women didn‚Äôt go out to meetings‚Ä¶ but now they know they have the right to participate."

Thanks to supporters like you, women like Maria are building brighter futures. Not just for themselves, but for their entire community. ‚ù§Ô∏è

#FoodForTheHungry #FHStories #WomenEmpowered #EndPovertyTogether

media.ocrText: May be an image of 1 person, child, smiling and tree
May be an image of 1 person

text:
We gave kids a camera and asked them to take a picture of what they find beautiful in the world.

Ratha, age 15, photographed his mother. He says, ‚ÄúI photographed my mother because I love her. I love her because she gave me life and she does her best in everything for me. She is my shield and shelter. She makes me feel warmth and she is the smile of the family.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere is no time left for anything ‚Äî not even to play.‚Äù 

Edna‚Äôs daily burden of fetching dirty water is putting her life in danger and drowning her dreams. 

Without clean water, girls like her are caught in a crushing cycle of sickness, missed school, poverty, and exhaustion.  

But your overflowing love can break that. You can open the door to clean water and a future filled with possibilities. 

Jesus told us that whatever we do for the least of these, we do for Him. Today, will you be His hands and feet to a child who‚Äôs crying out for help?  

Your urgent gift will help build wells and water tanks, drill new boreholes, deliver water filters and more to let clean water flow.  

Your love in action will be a turning point in a child like Enda‚Äôs story.  

Edna dreams of becoming a teacher or leader‚Ä¶ someone her siblings can look up to. With your help, she can go to school, stay healthy, and build the future God intends for her.  

Clean water doesn‚Äôt just quench thirst. It restores hope, safety, and opportunity. Your generous heart can do so much. Please give your best gift today.

You helped Laurence learn to read, and feel like a winner! 

Laurence, a bright young girl in Rwanda, is so grateful for the reading club and library of books her sponsor helped provide. 

‚ÄúWhen I come to the library, I meet my friends, and we read, enjoy ourselves and laugh,‚Äù she says.

Watch Laurence‚Äôs thank-you message and see how her sponsor is helping her write a new story for her life.

Thanks to her sponsor‚Äôs kindness and her hard work, she‚Äôs learning and flourishing. 

üíö This is love in action.

We‚Äôre honored to walk alongside communities around the world, helping children and families access the education they deserve. 

#LiteracyDay #EducationChangesEverything #HopeInAction #FoodfortheHungry

text:
A prayer for students and teachers üôè

Dear Heavenly Father,

As a new school year begins, we lift up every child and teacher to You.

Give students courage to learn and grow, and fill teachers with strength and wisdom as they guide them.

Thank you for the gift of education. May this school year be full of hope, joyful growth, and Your presence wrapped around the children we love.
 
In Jesus‚Äô name, amen.

text:
International Day of Charity: A Call to Empower üôåüèΩ üôåüèª üôåüèº üôåüèæ

International Day of Charity, observed each year on September 5, is a United Nations initiative to highlight the power of charity, philanthropy, and volunteerism in tackling global challenges. The day was established in 2012 to honor the legacy of Mother Teresa, who devoted her life to serving the poor.

At Food for the Hungry, we see this day as more than remembrance. It‚Äôs a reminder that true charity is about creating space for others to rise. Charity is a vessel that connects kind people (like you!) to families who are ready to seize opportunity, build resilience, and flip the odds stacked against them.

On this International Day of Charity, let‚Äôs celebrate not only acts of kindness but the incredible agency of those who, when empowered, become the authors of their own transformation.

üíö Ways You Can Get Involved üíö

‚ú¥ Donate: Give to empower families with tools and opportunities to overcome poverty. fh.org/shine

‚ú¥ Sponsor a Child: Build a life-changing relationship that helps a child and their family thrive.

‚ú¥ Volunteer: Share your time and talents with us. Learn more at fh.org/volunteer

‚ú¥ Pray & Advocate: Lift up families around the world and help share their stories.

#InternationalDayOfCharity  #foodforthehungry

media.ocrText: May be an image of 3 people

text:
Long-time supporter Jonathan from Phoenix says his parents taught him to be generous from a young age: ‚ÄúMy parents showed me that we give because we‚Äôve been given so much.‚Äù  

Now with children of his own, Jonathan has included Food for the Hungry in his estate plan to extend that ripple effect of generous love in his family.

‚ÄúThis will take care of the people I love and are closest to me,‚Äù he says, ‚Äúbut will also allow me to broaden that circle and take care of others.‚Äù

It means his trust will continue the deep values and beliefs of his life, providing for his children as well as opening doors and opportunities for other children in need.

Like Jonathan, if you include Food for the Hungry in your estate plan, you can make a lasting impact for generations to come.
 
Now is the perfect time to create or update your Will, and we can help you do it for free.  

Find out more about this simple, safe way to create your Will online, at no cost to you.

There is no obligation to include a gift to Food for the Hungry. This is our way of helping you protect your loved ones and your peace of mind. 

fh.org/freewill

text:
You made education 'beautiful' for Chantra ü•∞

We gave children cameras and asked them to photograph something they thought was beautiful in their community. So Chantra, a sponsored child from Cambodia, took this surprising snapshot‚Ä¶ of her school!

‚ÄúI photographed my school because I love it,‚Äù says Chantra.

‚ÄúIt is a nice school. There are trees in front that give shade for students to relax and read.‚Äù

Because of you, Chantra‚Äôs school is more than just a building. It‚Äôs a safe place where she can learn, play with friends, and reach for her dreams. Thank you for making school a place of joy and beauty for children like Chantra.

text:
üíß Clean Water For ALL!

‚ÄúMy children‚Äôs health has improved, and now they can attend school regularly.‚Äù 
‚Äî Qabale Guyo, Dololo Dokatu, Kenya 

Over the past year, Food for the Hungry Kenya has partnered with the Dololo Dokatu Farmer Group to transform lives through access to clean water and climate-smart farming.

‚úÖ Water system pipeline extensions
‚úÖ Borehole rehabilitation & storage tanks
‚úÖ Seeds, inputs & training in soil maintenance

Today, families like Qabale‚Äôs are thriving. From bananas and kale to spinach and fodder, harvests are replacing hunger with health, hope, and opportunity. 

#FoodForTheHungry #WorldWaterWeek #Kenya #CleanWater

media.ocrText: May be an image of ‚Äé5 people and ‚Äétext that says '‚Äéÿ¢0 ODAY WORLD WATER WEEK‚Äé'‚Äé‚Äé

text:
üíî Willy, a young father in Bolivia, once faced the heartbreaking choice of leaving his community. 

Severe water shortages made farming nearly impossible and put his family‚Äôs livelihood at risk.
But Willy and his neighbors didn‚Äôt give up. Together with support from Food for the Hungry Bolivia, the Sumaj Pampa (‚ÄúGood Land‚Äù) irrigation system was transformed with advanced drip and sprinkler methods, plus ongoing technical training.

‚ú® The results have been remarkable:
Fruit production doubled üçä
Water flow increased üíß
More than 40 hectares are now irrigated üå±
Local jobs grew, and families no longer feel forced to migrate

Today, Willy looks to the future with confidence and joy, not fear. His community is thriving because they had the tools, training, and agency to create lasting change.

üôå We thank God for using partners like you to bless Willy, his family, and his community with water and hope.

‚û°Ô∏è This #WorldWaterWeek, you can help more families like Willy‚Äôs. Give today and be part of bringing clean, reliable water to vulnerable communities around the world. fh.org/GiveWaterOnline

media.ocrText: May be an image of 5 people and text

text:
üåçüíß World Water Week: Celebrating Change, Dignity, and Resilience üíßüåç

For Sifa, 20, from Irune village in Mozambique, water once meant survival filled with hardship. ‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt just a matter of arriving and collecting water. There was always a line, and sometimes it took us more than three hours just to fill one bucket,‚Äù she recalls. The unsafe water caused sickness: ‚ÄúThat water wasn‚Äôt good; it gave us a lot of diarrhea.‚Äù

Everything changed when Food for the Hungry rehabilitated the village water pump after Cyclone Chido. Now, more than 1,100 people have daily access to safe water. 

üíß For Sifa and her siblings, this means life with dignity restored. ‚ÄúNow we can go to the fields without any problem because we know the water is nearby. When we return, we fetch water from the pump and cook,‚Äù she says proudly.

üíß The difference is clear in health and in hope. ‚ÄúNow we drink clean water, and we no longer suffer from diarrhea like before. We are very thankful to Food for the Hungry for rehabilitating this pump for us.‚Äù

We celebrate the power of safe water to transform lives - turning hours of struggle into time for farming, learning, and thriving. 

‚ú® For Sifa, clean water is more than convenience. It is strength. It is independence. It is dignity. 

#WorldWaterDay #WaterIsLife #CleanWater #Wateriseverything #Mozambique #FoodForTheHungry

media.ocrText: May be an image of 2 people, child and body of water

text:
Will you let a child drink dirty water‚Äîor turn on the tap?  

If you‚Äôre a child like Edna in Mozambique, you have no choice but to drink dirty, disease-ridden water. And it‚Äôs a price no child should have to pay.  

According to the World Health Organization, some 1,000 children under the age of 5 die each day because of unsafe water and sanitation. 

That‚Äôs 40 kindergarten classes of children just disappearing from planet earth ‚Äî into eternity ‚Äî because the water they drink kills them rather than quenches their thirst.
 
Every day without clean water puts Edna‚Äôs life and future at risk.  

But your overflowing love today can bring safe, clean water by delivering wells, water tanks, filters and more, before it‚Äôs too late. 

Your urgent gift means children like Edna can walk a shorter path ‚Äì just steps from their door ‚Äì to clean, safe, disease-free water. But she can‚Äôt do it without you.   

Please give now and let your love in action be a turning point in a child‚Äôs story. There‚Äôs no time to waste. 

Give at fh.org/givewateronline

#worldwaterweek #cleanwater #cleanwaterforall #waterweek

media.ocrText: May be an image of 3 people

text:
You trained teachers like Ms. Felista in Uganda, and now more children love learning!

Because you cared, children in Uganda have teachers who are trained, confident and ready to inspire.

Ms. Felista is one of them. She‚Äôs a dedicated primary school teacher who used to struggle with limited skills and large class sizes.

Thanks to generous supporters like you, she was trained in early childhood education and child-friendly teaching methods to help her ignite a love for learning in her students.

‚ÄúI learned to put God at the center of everything I do, even in difficult situations,‚Äù says Ms. Felista.

‚ÄúThis training transformed me and the community. It spurred a spike in school enrollment, giving more children access to education and a promising future.‚Äù

Once frustrated, now empowered, she says, "I wish to see my students grow up to become future leaders who can take care of themselves.‚Äù

Thank you for equipping teachers like Ms. Felista to transform young lives by bringing out the best in their students and helping kids enjoy learning!

üëèüëèüëè And here‚Äôs a special round of applause for teachers in the U.S. who are also child sponsors. You are making an extraordinary difference. You‚Äôre equipping kids at home and around the world to reach their God-given potential. Thank you!

text: Happy Friday from the Philippines! ‚ù§Ô∏è

media.ocrText: May be an image of 1 person, child and smiling

text:
Why is this little girl happy? 

One reason may be that her daddy is home. ‚ù§Ô∏è

Because of your kindness, her father was able to stay in his village and work his farm instead of leaving to find illegal work in South Africa. With the improved seeds and tools he received, he grew more crops and even bought a cow.

Now this family has enough income to send their children to school, giving them hope and a future.

They did it! üëè

"Food for the Hungry helped me to face and solve problems. I met Jesus through FH, and now I have the challenge of reading the Bible every day with my family.‚Äù ‚úùÔ∏è

In Sucasuma, Bolivia, Daniel and his neighbors once faced life without a health clinic, little education, and not enough food to thrive. But when Daniel received training on health and nutrition, something powerful happened. He took action.

Daniel stepped up as a health agent for his rural village, urging his community to join together, learn, and put new practices into motion. And they did! 

Now, Daniel and his family are eating vegetables, baking bread, and living free from malnutrition. They even launched a family business selling bread - providing income and stability for the future. üéâ

This is the power of your generosity. 

üíö Because of kind donors like you, families like Daniel‚Äôs are building healthier lives, stronger communities, and walking with Jesus. They did it - and you helped unlock the possibility.

On #WorldHumanitarianDay we honor the courage of humanitarians worldwide. 

Our teams at Food for the Hungry walk with vulnerable communities in the hardest places, bringing hope and lasting change. Thank you for choosing love, service, and people first. ü´∂

At a primary school in Cambodia, students faced challenges like broken toilets, no handwashing stations, and unsafe drinking water, making it hard for many to attend and stay healthy.

With community leadership and generous support from people like you, new latrines were built, hygiene kits provided, and clean water filters installed. Students learned important hygiene habits, and school attendance and graduation rates improved.

Thank you for standing alongside communities as they build a brighter future. üè´

#FoodForTheHungry #StrengtheningCommunities #SustainableChange #TogetherWeFlourish

text:
It all starts with water. üíß

Clean water unlocks education, opportunity, and hope for children and their communities.

fh.org/GiveWateronline

#FoodFortheHungry #CleanWater #WaterIsLife #CleanWaterForAll

‚ÄúSometimes, girls don‚Äôt join in much during science or math.‚Äù

That‚Äôs what Professor Wilfredo noticed in his classroom in Huancavelica, Peru. But this year, things are changing.

He joined a new project to help teachers use fun STEM lessons that encourage every student, especially girls, to get involved.

‚ÄúI realized we can motivate them more,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI want to keep learning how to use these ideas in class.‚Äù

Students are already feeling the difference. One 10-year-old girl, Mar√≠a, said: ‚ÄúIt made me feel proud. I want to do it again and learn more.‚Äù

With your support and help from UNICEF and local schools, children are learning that they all belong in science. And this is only the beginning. üìöüß™

#STEMforGirls #HopeStartsHere #GirlsInSTEM #FoodForTheHungry #Peru #GenderEquality #EducationForAll #UNICEF

Today, on International Youth Day, we‚Äôre celebrating the courage, creativity, and determination of young people around the world. üéâ

In the communities we serve, youth are stepping into leadership, gaining education, and developing skills that create lasting change. With the support of people like you, they are building a brighter future for themselves and their communities.

#InternationalYouthDay #YouthEmpowerment #FoodForTheHungry

‚ÄúI feel disturbed and sad at school. I don‚Äôt know how to read.‚Äù  

Kids like 8-year-old Beniella are hungry to read but need your help. 

Your love today will help girls and boys learn to read so they can stay in school, safe from child labor and child marriage.  

Your generosity will open the door to a future filled with possibilities.  

Your gift of $40 today will help a child like Beniella learn to read‚Äîand reach their God-given potential. Please give at fh.org/LetsRead
Happy Friday üíö

August is National Breastfeeding Month!

Margarita began nutrition training with Food for the Hungry when her daughter Petrona was six months old. The nutrition program includes education and breastfeeding training.

Petrona suffered from low birth weight and Margarita didn‚Äôt know about the dangers of malnutrition before. 

Through this valuable training, she learned about malnutrition, how to best care for Petrona and how her baby is a gift from God. 

After a short time, her daughter was healthy and gaining weight. This photo is of Margarita and Petrona, a happy and healthy 2-year-old. ü´∂üèº

Providing mothers valuable nutrition training is part of our work to strengthen communities to flourish.

#nationalbreastfeedingmonth #breastfeedingmonth

‚ÄúThis opportunity is a true blessing‚Ä¶ a long-awaited dream that became a reality through divine providence.‚Äù ‚Äì Community Leader, Los Rincones

Meet Sugelis Ramires Montero. She is a mother, a leader, and a relentless force for good in Los Rincones. She and others in her community dreamed of building a place where youth could gather, where adults could learn, and where neighbors could come together in unity.

ü´∂Thanks to your generosity, the community center in Los Rincones stands as a symbol of what‚Äôs possible when people come together with purpose and hope. But more than bricks and cement, what has been built is something deeper: dignity, ownership, and lasting change.

This is empowerment.

Through leadership workshops and grassroots unity, the people of Los Rincones are stepping boldly into their God-given potential. They organized and lead this charge themselves, with Food for the Hungry walking alongside them.

üíö Over 3,000 people benefit
üíõ 1,000 children and youth gained access to safe, enriching spaces
üíô 1,800 women and men are directly impacted
‚ù§Ô∏è All of it made possible by your support

Your support ignites transformation by believing in them as they do it with their own hands and hearts.

From all of us at Food for the Hungry and the people of Los Rincones: thank you for investing in people, in potential, and in God‚Äôs beautiful work of restoration.

#ThankYou #CommunityTransformation #FHDonors #LosRincones #RealChange #FaithInAction #HopeBuilders #DevelopmentWithDignity #FoodForTheHungry #YouMadeThisPossible

Did you know we facilitate children's clubs in many of the communities we work in worldwide? 

These after-school clubs give children extra support for their education, time to connect with other kids their age and an opportunity to learn about Christ's love.

üôåüèΩ

üçé‚ÄúEven a single apple changed my life.‚Äù ‚Äì Iskandar 

Iskandar grew up in a small coastal village in Indonesia where opportunities were scarce and economic hardship was the norm. But when FH arrived in his community, everything began to shift.

What started with simple curiosity turned into a life of transformation. Through Kids Clubs, leadership training, and mentorship from facilitators like Mesrika and Pak Dalsen, Iskandar discovered something powerful: the will to learn could change everything. üíö

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no pessimism in my life when it comes to the desire to learn,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúEven if the economic situation is challenging, if we truly have the will to pursue our goals, we can definitely achieve them.‚Äù

And he did.

Today, Iskandar is a village secretary, a teacher of Pancasila and Civic Education, and a small business owner whose crab and anchovy business supports the local economy. He helps govern his village with wisdom and humility, teaches the next generation, and lives out what it means to give back.

‚ÄúWithout Food for the Hungry, I don‚Äôt know if I would be who I am today.‚Äù

His journey is a powerful reminder: when children are supported, believed in, and given the tools to grow, they don‚Äôt just change their own future - they change their entire community.

#WhereAreTheyNow #FoodForTheHungry #Indonesia #Transformation #Resilience #FHImpact #CommunityChange #RealStories #HopeInAction

‚ÄúGive your hands to serve and your hearts to love.‚Äù
‚ù§Ô∏è Mother Teresa

üìù August is Make-A-Will Month ... but this isn‚Äôt just about paperwork.

It‚Äôs about putting your love into action and leaving behind a legacy that empowers people to walk boldly in God‚Äôs calling.

When you include Food for the Hungry in your will, you're not just passing down assets ‚Äî you're passing on hope, opportunity, and freedom to children and families around the world. You're saying, ‚ÄúI believe in a world where God's love changes everything.‚Äù

This is your moment to shape a legacy that reflects what matters most.

üíô Ready to make a will that empowers others to thrive?

Check our our FREE Will‚Äôs Guide to make it simple for you to complete your legal will online. It‚Äôs an easy, powerful way to care for the people and causes you love and to make a lasting difference in the world.

Start today and let your love outlive you. Go to: FHLegacy.org.

Have you seen what happens when a child learns to read? 

‚ú®Their eyes light up. Their voice gains confidence. Their whole world opens. 

Right now, kids like 8-year-old Beniella are hungry to read but these precious girls and boys need your help before they‚Äôre forced to drop out of school. 

In Burundi where Beniella lives, teachers and students are struggling so much, only 4% of all 10-year-olds can read and understand a simple story. 

Your generosity means kids like Beniella will be able to join a powerful reading program for grades 1‚Äì3 so they can become confident in reading ‚Äî and in life. 

Your kindness means girls and boys will experience the thrill of reading books in their own language, solving math problems in a fun playful way, exploring their environment through science, and feeling confident in discovering new ideas! üíö

You hold such a powerful gift in your hands! Your caring donation of $40 today will help a child like Beniella learn to read and open the door to a future filled with possibilities.  üìö

Give at:

Today is World Day Against Trafficking

Human trafficking steals futures. At Food for the Hungry, we work to break the cycle of poverty that traffickers exploit‚Äîempowering families, educating children, and building safer communities.

Today, let‚Äôs raise our voices for freedom.
Together, we can protect the vulnerable and restore dignity.

#EndTrafficking #FoodForTheHungry #FreedomForAll #WorldDayAgainstTrafficking

üö®Emergency Aid and Relief Update:

As we previously shared, Bolivia‚Äôs life-threatening wildfires destroyed crops and left families struggling for food and water. 

We‚Äôre thrilled to let you know that your great generosity helped provide emergency food, water, healthcare, seeds, and more to help families survive this crisis. 

Maximiliano, father of two young sons, has this message for you: ‚ÄúAll the aid was a relief because... we suffered greatly. The fire came within 500 meters of the community, and we had to control it ourselves. The food was very helpful for all the families. 

‚ÄúRight now, community members are starting to plant again (with the seeds you provided). People have vegetable gardens around their homes and are harvesting. Blessings to everyone over there.‚Äù

Mother-of-three Rafaela says: ‚ÄúThe food really helped us during the days we were worried, especially since I lost all my crops due to the fire. Also, the hygiene supplies were useful for cleaning and washing clothes for the family. I thank you for supporting us.‚Äù

Thank you for your overflowing love for children and families who lost so much in these fires. Your kindness helped communities survive. With your generosity by their side, families are rising from the ashes and rebuilding their lives.

üî• How Hot Does It Get?

While summer heats up here in the U.S., the country where your sponsored child lives can feel the heat too‚Äîwith some countries topping 95¬∞F or more!

üíõAfrica: Ethiopia, Kenya, Mozambique, and Uganda can reach up to 95¬∞F, especially in lowland areas.

üíöLatin America: Bolivia, Guatemala, Haiti, and parts of Peru can soar to 100¬∞F, especially inland.

üíôAsia: Bangladesh and Vietnam can hit 104¬∞F in peak months like April and June. With that in mind‚Ä¶.

‚ùÑÔ∏è Cool Off with a Vietnamese-Inspired Lime & Lychee Drink ‚ùÑÔ∏è

This refreshing and fragrant drink features coconut water (good for healthy hydration), limes, and lychees‚Äîa popular summer fruit in Vietnam where it‚Äôs known as the ‚Äúfruit of love".

ü•• Ingredients (to serve 2):
8 lychees (fresh or canned)  
Juice of 2 limes 
2 tablespoons sugar (or syrup from can, to taste)
1 cup coconut water
1 cup sparkling water 
2-3 springs fresh mint leaves 
Ice

Directions:
1Ô∏è‚É£ Lightly mash or coarsely chop the lychees. 
2Ô∏è‚É£ Add the lychees to a pitcher with lime juice, sugar (or syrup from can), coconut water, and sparkling water. 
3Ô∏è‚É£ Pour into serving glasses with lots of ice. Add a slice of lime, a sprig of mint and enjoy!

Jean de Dieu says he felt hopeless growing up in poverty in Rwanda, until his life was transformed by a kind sponsor like you. 

Today, he‚Äôs a skilled tradesman (he built his own home!), loving husband, father, and a man of faith who generously gives back to others in need. 

Jean is living proof of the difference your sponsorship makes and the ripple effect of your generosity across generations. 

‚ñ∂Ô∏è Watch the VIDEO: https://www.fh.org/give/child-sponsorship/meet-jean

üôè Pray for Peace in Cambodia and Thailand

Tensions along the border near the Ta Moan Temple area have disrupted daily life for many communities. We are deeply concerned for all those impacted by the current situation.

Please join us in praying for peace, protection for displaced families, and strength for those serving in affected areas.

Jewelie‚Äôs Gem of a Summer Trip: Meeting Her Sponsored Child!

After Jewelie visited Massiel, her sponsored child in Dominican Republic, she posted this on social media: ‚ÄúMany years sponsoring a child with Food for the Hungry! Today was a prayer answered. I was able to meet her and her family.

Later, she told us: ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs something incredibly powerful about being face-to-face. It reminds you that what we do matters‚Äînot just in theory, but in real life, with real people. This visit has changed me‚Ä¶‚Äù

üì∏ See why this trip was so life-changing for both Jewelie and Massiel (and what ‚ÄòMofongo‚Äô tastes like!): Read more!

https://www.fh.org/blog/jewelies-gem-of-a-summer-trip-meeting-her-sponsored-child/

For American kids, warm summer days mean jumping in the pool, splashing in a lake, or running through water sprinklers. 

But for children in communities where water is scarce, hot days mean longer and more exhausting walks to fetch heavy buckets of water.

That‚Äôs why your kindness in helping to bring clean water to children and families in Mozambique is so life-changing! 

This new water pump means no more daily treks for water in the hot sun. Clean water is just steps away, bringing kids joy and relief, and letting good health flow. 

This water pump gives families a very practical demonstration of God‚Äôs love pouring out through supporters like you.

As community leader Antonio says: 

‚ÄúThis pump has helped not only the people in this community but also everyone who passes by this road, stopping to drink water here because it‚Äôs fresh and sweet.‚Äù 

This is your impact. Thank you!

Our hearts are with the people of Bangladesh following Monday‚Äôs tragic plane crash in Dhaka (July 21). We are grieving alongside the families, especially those who lost precious children. Please join us in praying for healing, comfort, and strength during this heartbreaking time. üíîüôè

üìö Back-to-School is here! ‚úèÔ∏è
It‚Äôs that special time when children across the globe return to the classroom, and your encouragement means the everything to them!

If you sponsor a child through Food for the Hungry, don‚Äôt forget to send back your Back-to-School message and that colorful ruler we sent you by mail! It‚Äôs a small gift that makes a big impact. üì®

And if you‚Äôd like to bless children through our "Let's Learn To Read" program and more, you can give today at FH.org/learntoread.

Let‚Äôs remind these students they are loved, capable, and never alone on their learning journey. 

#BackToSchool #FoodForTheHungry #ChildSponsorship #PrayForStudents #GlobalClassroom #EndPovertyTogether

üì¨ Did you see it?

Our July eNewsletter hit inboxes this morning - packed with impact stories, photos, and ways you are making a difference around the world. üåç‚ú®

Not on the list yet? Sign up at FH.org! Just scroll to the bottom of the homepage!

‚ú® A special delivery, straight from the heart!

There‚Äôs nothing quite like the moment a child receives a letter from their sponsor. üíõ

Even in the most remote areas, Food for the Hungry staff make the journey to deliver messages of love, hope, and encouragement. When we show up, it‚Äôs not just a visit, it‚Äôs a celebration - sometimes for the whole family!

Because every child deserves to be seen, known, and loved.

Want to bring joy like this to a child‚Äôs life? Sponsor today or send your sponsored child a letter at fh.org.

#FoodForTheHungry #ChildSponsorship #HopeDelivered #EndPovertyTogether #LettersOfLove #FaithInAction #FHOnTheMove

During a recent visit to Tanore and Ukhiya (in Bangladesh), our CEO Mark Viso and Chief Programs and Public Resource Officer Kate were welcomed with open arms (and flowers!) from a grateful young boy. üíê 

This beautiful gesture reflects the heart of Food for the Hungry‚Äôs mission: walking in partnership with communities as they rise out of poverty and pursue their God-given potential.

In Tanore, Mark and Kate visited early childhood centers, schools, savings groups, and fishery cooperatives, where families are building new futures through training in literacy, entrepreneurship, and sustainable farming. 

In Ukhiya, they explored clean water projects, education programs, and child development efforts that are opening doors for those once marginalized.

We‚Äôre honored to stand beside families as they create brighter futures on their own terms.

And we‚Äôre grateful to share these moments with you, offering a window into their world, their resilience, and their incredible progress.

We love sharing #ThrowbackThursday photos with you! 

Pictured here are Maasai children waiting for Food for the Hungry staff to deliver much-needed milk. This photo (circa 1970s) was provided by our first Country Director in Kenya.

#tbt #tbthursday

Meet the Girls Changing Rwanda üá∑üáº

Poverty, cultural barriers, and household duties once stood in their way. But today, Grace, Aimee, Jeanne, and Muhorakeye are rewriting what‚Äôs possible for girls in Rwanda ‚Äî and it all began with education, clean water, and the support of generous people like you.

üíú Grace, 12, is a top student.
ü©∑ Aimee, 12, uses poetry to empower girls to find their voice.
üíõ Jeanne, 20, graduated from tailoring school and is earning her own income.
ü©µ Muhorakeye, 23, is leading change through modern farming.

They are daughters. They are leaders. They are proof that when girls are empowered, whole communities rise.

These transformations didn‚Äôt happen by chance. They happened because someone believed in their potential.

Your support breaks barriers. Your gifts open doors.

Donate today and walk alongside the next girl who dares to dream:
fh.org/shine

#FoodForTheHungry #GirlsEducation #EndPoverty #Rwanda #EmpowerHer #HopeInAction
Today is #MalalaDay! Join us as we recognize and celebrate women and girls around the globe who are pursuing their education and those who are fighting for the right to education for all.
Happy Friday from Ethiopia! üíö

#throwbackthursday

10 years ago at this time, University Presbyterian Church (UPC) of Seattle is visited the community of San Juan de Lurigancho, Peru, and shared many beautiful moments with the children and parents. 

On this trip, they helped the community's dream come true by building a recreational park and provided many activities to show Christ's love. 

A huge thank you to UPC Seattle for their partnership and love in action!

Our hearts are with Texas.

Many in our Food for the Hungry family -  volunteers, sponsors, donors, and friends - call Texas home. In this time of devastation and loss, we lift up every community affected by the floods.

üôè Join us in praying for Texas.

#PrayForTexas

"We have sponsored multiple children through FH for over a decade. We receive pictures and notes throughout the years, allowing us to watch kids grow up and thrive. During this COVID-19 season of distancing my husband and I wanted to help our 5 kids see that they could make a difference in lives around the world. The Food for the hungry Gift Catalog came, and we knew how the kids could participate from home. We gave the kids "money" to spend. Each of our children went through the catalog, looking at the pictures, asking questions, and picking gifts for others. The impact Food for the Hungry makes on our world even changes children's hearts and attitudes in Colorado. I highly recommend giving to this organization. They seek to help through providing sustainable skills as well as emergency life-giving necessities to the poorest of nations." ‚ÄîChristy

We are so grateful to those of you who have been a part of the Food for the Hungry family. Whether you've been with us for 30 years or 30 minutes, we are grateful for your heart to serve the most vulnerable around the world.

Find the Gift Catalog at www.fh.org/gifts

Sponsor Spotlight: Michael Nothum
‚ÄúIt's truly a privilege to partner with you and the Food for the Hungry Guatemala staff. Witnessing the growth of these young individuals in their faith and their commitment to bettering themselves, their families, and their community is a powerful testament to what God can achieve through faithful obedience. In a place where daily hardships are evident, their progress is such an encouragement.‚Äù ü´∂

In Rwanda, Igisoro is a game that holds deep cultural significance. It‚Äôs a traditional mancala game played on a wooden board with small pits and seeds or stones as playing pieces. Far more than just a game, Igisoro teaches strategic thinking, patience, and brings generations together.

#FoodForTheHungry #Rwanda #FridayInspiration #TraditionalGames #Community

"I clung onto that promise so fiercely and dreamed of advancing past elementary school despite the high rate of school dropout... because girls were told they didn‚Äôt have the right to go to school."

When Amalia finished 6th grade in rural Guatemala, her parents didn‚Äôt plan to send her to middle school.

They believed girls didn‚Äôt need more schooling. The cost was too high. And she was the oldest of five children - how could they give that opportunity to just one?

But Amalia wasn‚Äôt willing to give up.

‚≠ï So she went on a hunger strike.
‚≠ï She refused to eat.
‚≠ï She hid in bed for days.

And eventually‚Ä¶ it worked.

Her parents made the sacrifice. They enrolled her in school. And it changed everything.

Today, Amalia is not only the first in her family to finish high school, she's now a staff member at Food for the Hungry, helping other children receive the same chance.

üíõ Her story is a reminder of how determination + sponsorship = generational change.

üëâ Stay tuned: In the next few days, we‚Äôll be sharing more powerful stories of families in Food for the Hungry Guatemala, told by Amalia herself.

Imagine waking up knowing your kids will go to school without a bath because there's no clean water nearby.

That was everyday life for Antonio‚Äôs family in Mozambique. The closest water pump was over a mile away. During the rainy season, it was nearly impossible to reach.

‚ÄúMy wife used to carry heavy buckets for so long,‚Äù Antonio said. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôd come home from the fields too tired to wash. My children went to school dirty. We lived like that for years.‚Äù

But now, everything is different.

Thanks to supporters like you, there‚Äôs a water pump right in Antonio‚Äôs neighborhood. It flows with clean, fresh water‚Äîand life has changed.

üí¨ ‚ÄúThis pump helps everyone who passes by,‚Äù Antonio says. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve even built a space to wash clothes nearby. Life feels lighter now.‚Äù

Today, 938 families like Antonio‚Äôs have safe water close to home.

This pump doesn‚Äôt just bring water. It brings health. Dignity. Hope. It saves time so families can focus on what matters most‚Äîlike school, work, and rest.

This is one step toward a better future. Your kindness helps build more water pumps, schools, and programs that change lives in Mozambique and beyond.

üôè Thank you for walking with families like Antonio‚Äôs.

For 18-year-old Travis, helping his mom share food during Holy Week is more than tradition ‚Äî it‚Äôs a way to give back and say thanks for the blessings his family has received.

Living with a health condition that makes daily life challenging, Travis still dreams big: to become a teacher who inspires others.

With the support and connections provided through supporters like you, Travis‚Äôs family has been able to access medical care and community programs that bring hope and strength.

Imagine the power of hope and kindness passed from one generation to the next.

üôè Thank you for being a part of Travis‚Äô story.

#GivingThanks #HopeInAction #FoodForTheHungry #FaithAndCommunity #BrightFutures

‚ÄúWe used to walk two hours for water,‚Äù says Tadelech, a mom of two in Ethiopia. ‚ÄúMy children‚Äôs backs hurt from carrying heavy jugs. They missed school, and we were always sick.‚Äù

For years, families in her village lived without clean water‚Äîfacing long walks, constant illness, and missed opportunities. Kids stayed home. Parents spent what little they had on medicine.

With the support of compassionate people like you, water points were built near Tadelech‚Äôs home. Today, her family‚Äîand 3,200 of their neighbors‚Äîcan drink, wash, and live healthier lives.

üíß Can you imagine the joy of giving your child clean water, right in your own village?

You‚Äôre part of that change. üíõ

Learn more at: fh.org/water

#CleanWaterChangesEverything #FoodForTheHungry #HopeInAction #WaterIsLife #WASH #BrightFutures

Can you imagine if all you had to feed your starving baby was water mixed with sugar?

For Gebrie, a mother in Ethiopia, that heartbreaking reality is all she had left to give her 8-month-old daughter, Ashine. Drought has taken their crops, their livestock, and their hope. Without food, children like Ashine will not survive.

Please put your faith into action to bring hope and life-saving help to a mother like Gebrie and a child like Ashine as a reflection of God‚Äôs life-saving love. 

There‚Äôs not a minute to waste. Your urgent gift will make a life-saving difference for hungry children like Ashine by providing families with food, water, and other essentials they need to survive.

üíö Give now: fh.org/urgent

text:
Meet Althea, 8 years old and full of hope.

‚ÄúI want to be a doctor to help sick people,‚Äù she says. üíô

When Typhoon Kristine flooded her home in the Philippines, Althea and her family had to evacuate to her school. Her mom, Cristy, shares, ‚ÄúThe flood reached our bed. We slept on a boat, waiting for morning.‚Äù

But Althea wasn‚Äôt scared. She held her doll, played with other kids, and felt safe because she was with her family.

Thanks to supporters like you, Althea‚Äôs family learned how to prepare for disasters. They had already packed a Go Bag with food, clothes, and essentials, so they were ready at a moment‚Äôs notice. üéí

Can you imagine how your support helps kids like Althea face floods in the Philippines‚Äîand build brighter futures?

#HopeInAction #DisasterRelief #FaithAndCommunity #FoodForTheHungry #BrightFutures

A grateful teenager says: ‚ÄúI love my father so much!‚Äù  
 
It‚Äôs wonderful to see how Akash, a sponsored child in Bangladesh, is so thankful for all the love being shown to him by his father. Your sponsorship empowers dads (and moms) to earn stable family income and be the best parents they can be.  
 
‚ÄúI love my dad, my Abba. He always meets my needs. He works laboriously to give me enough food to eat and to provide me with a good education. He never wants anything for himself, but instead always wants me to be happy. I love him so much!‚Äù says Akash. 
 
In case you‚Äôre wondering why Akash and his dad aren‚Äôt smiling: 
 üáßüá© In Bangladesh, people are often serious in photos as a sign of respect. 
üôÇ Smiles are abundant when the cameras are gone.

At a health center in Sena, Mozambique, moms once gave birth without running water. Staff walked to nearby houses to beg for water, but when none was available, families had to fill heavy jugs from distant sources and carry them back while their loved ones waited anxiously for care.

‚ÄúWe had to pay neighbors or walk for water, even during emergencies,‚Äù says Francisco, a doctor at the clinic. ‚ÄúBut now, thanks to this water system, we have clean water, day and night.‚Äù

Because of supporters like you, this health center‚Äîand over 1,500 people in the community‚Äînow have safe, reliable water through a new piped system that brings clean water directly into the health center. Mothers deliver their babies in clean rooms. Families no longer worry about cholera outbreaks. Staff can focus on healing, not hauling water.

üíß Can you imagine how it feels to bring your child into the world in safety and dignity?

You‚Äôre part of that hope.

#CleanWaterChangesEverything #HopeInAction #FoodForTheHungry #WaterIsLife #WASH #BrightFutures

Hunger is...working as a child so your family can eat.

In many communities, traditional gender roles have decided who held the household responsibilities, often limiting opportunities for both men and women. 

Ato, a father in Ethiopia, believed household chores were solely a woman‚Äôs responsibility, while men worked in the fields. But when his wife, Mulu, fell seriously ill, he needed to take on the household duties himself. Without time to work, the family quickly faced financial strain.

Consequently, their 3 sons left school to assist with household chores and farming to sustain the family's livelihood. 

After participating in gender equality training, Ato began learning how to share household responsibilities with his wife, and once she recovered, she began contributing to agricultural tasks as well. This collaboration improved their family's income, allowing their children to return to school and focus on their education. üôå 

Your generous support empowers families like Ato's to access resources and education that promote gender equality and alleviate the burdens leading to child labor during crises. ü§ù 

#FoodForTheHungry #HungerIs #EndHunger #Education #ChildreninSchool #GenderEquality

Let kids be kids.

Every child deserves a safe, joyful, and hope-filled childhood. But for millions of children around the world, childhood is marked by hunger, hard labor, and missed opportunities.

Instead of dreaming about what they want to be, they‚Äôre focused on surviving today.

Consider making room in your heart for a child in need. Through child sponsorship, you can help children around the world stay in school, grow up healthy, and simply be kids again‚Äîfull of potential, curiosity, and hope.

Visit fh.org/sponsor to learn more about how you can give children the chance to just be kids again.

#LetKidsBeKids #EveryChildMatters #ChildSponsorship #FoodForTheHungry

This Father‚Äôs Day, we‚Äôre honoring the quiet courage of dads who chose a new path‚Äîfor their own families and for generations to come.

Fathers like Kidat in Ethiopia, who once followed traditional norms that left his wife, Aletu, feeling unheard and unseen.

‚ÄúI held back my thoughts, feelings, and needs,‚Äù Aleut said.

Kidat didn‚Äôt realize how deeply that hurt his family until they joined a gender training session made possible with support from people like you.

ü§ù That‚Äôs when everything started to change.

He began listening. They started deciding together. He stood with Aletu as an equal and saw their children thrive in the process.

üí¨ ‚ÄúNow, we support each other. We decide together. We‚Äôre building something better for our children.‚Äù

Fathers like Kidat are choosing connection over control. And that kind of love creates safer, stronger homes‚Äîtoday and for the future.

This Father‚Äôs Day, you can help more dads walk alongside their families and raise children who feel seen, heard, and supported.

#FathersDay #FathersWhoStepUp #HopeStartsHere #FoodForTheHungry #StrongerTogether #Generations
Happy Friday from Bolivia! Zoila with her son Brayan. ü´∂

Today is World Day Against Child Labor ‚Äî a reminder that millions of children are still robbed of their childhoods.

More than 160 million children around the world are trapped in child labor, working long, dangerous hours just to help their families survive.

But it doesn‚Äôt have to be this way.

When you sponsor a child, you help provide what every child deserves ‚Äî safety, education, and a chance to simply be a child again. To learn. To dream. To grow into the person God created them to be. üìö

That‚Äôs the difference your support makes, and why these smiles are possible.

Be part of that change, one child at a time: fh.org/sponsor

#WorldDayAgainstChildLabour #WorldDayAgainstChildLabor

In Rwanda, Igisoro is a game that holds deep cultural significance. It‚Äôs a traditional mancala game played on a wooden board with small pits and seeds or stones as playing pieces. 

ü´∂ Far more than just a game, Igisoro teaches strategic thinking, patience, and brings generations together.

‚ÄúI have always believed in the power of transformation. When you invest in a child, you don‚Äôt just change their life‚Äîyou change a generation.‚Äù üíö Ammy, Dominican Republic 

As a former sponsored child, Ammy knows firsthand the life-changing difference a loving sponsor like you can make. ‚ÄúIf I had my sponsor in front of me, I would say thank you,‚Äù Ammy says. ‚ÄúEvery word they wrote carried a message of love.‚Äù 

Today, Ammy‚Äôs paying that generosity forward‚Äîthrough social work, leadership, and empowering the next generation of disadvantaged children to flip the odds from poverty to possibilities. Read Ammy‚Äôs story (link below) and see how a sponsor‚Äôs love can ignite a lifetime of purpose. 

#foodforthehungry #ChildSponsorship #SponsorshipStory #FaithInAction #SponsorshipChangesLives #HopeForTomorrow

Food for the Hungry CEO Mark Viso and Chief Programs and Public Resource Officer Kate Musimwa recently visited communities in Rajshahi and Cox‚Äôs Bazar, Bangladesh, where they witnessed firsthand the transformative work being done to uplift children and families. From early childhood education centers to women entrepreneurs, they saw the power of community-led development in action.

Through the support of compassionate donors like you, children are reaching their full potential and families are empowered to build sustainable livelihoods.

#EmpoweringCommunities #FoodForTheHungry #GlobalImpact #CommunityDevelopment #ChildEmpowerment #WomenInBusiness

In a recent trip to communities in Rajshahi, Bangladesh, Food for the Hungry‚Äôs CEO Mark Viso and Chief Programs and Public Resource Officer Kate Musimwa recently had the opportunity to see firsthand the incredible impact your support is helping to create. From vibrant cultural celebrations to entrepreneurial successes, they witnessed the power of community-driven change.

Women-led savings groups, the Let‚Äôs Learn to Read literacy program, and fishery training are just some of the ways supporters like you are encouraging communities to break the cycle of poverty.

Your generosity helps us create lasting change and build a brighter future for the next generation of children and families.

#SustainableChange #CommunityStrength #FoodForTheHungry #WomenEntrepreneurs #ChildEducation #TransformingLives

Hunger is... a risk to a child's brain development. 

In the first years of life, a child‚Äôs brain grows faster than at any other time, building the foundation for everything to come. But without enough nutritious food, that growth can slow or stall. And that has lifelong impacts on a child's health, learning, and later, ability to work. 

Two-year-old Xhaira from the Philippines was underweight, battling asthma attacks, and struggling to thrive. Her parents were doing their absolute best but poverty meant they couldn't provide her with enough nutritious food to grow healthy. With fresh fruit and vegetables out of reach, Xharia was missing out on essential nutrients.

Thanks to generous people like you, Xhaira received life-changing nutrition support through a 120-day supplementary feeding program. Your kindness also equipped her mom with training and resources to start growing fruit and vegetables at home in her garden. The results? In five months, Xhaira gained seven pounds and is growing healthy and strong.

Xhaira's mom now has a thriving garden, ensuring a continuous supply of nutritious food for her family. She has the skills and tools to stop malnutrition in its tracks.

This week as we celebrate #WorldHungerDay, Xhaira's story is a reminder that hunger affects families differently. It doesn't always look like famine. 

For her family, it looked like a toddler falling behind. Your kindness can make sure hunger doesn't rob a child of becoming all she was created to be. Your love can empower families like Xhaira's with the skills and tools they need to nourish their children in mind, body, and spirit. üå±

#FoodForTheHungry #HungerIs #WorldHungerDay #ChildNutrition #EarlyDevelopment #EndHunger

Hunger is... struggling to learn without the necessary tools and support. 

At just 11 years old, Mar√≠a from Guatemala was struggling to keep up in class.

Her family couldn‚Äôt afford school supplies. Her mom believed that school was a waste of time, especially since money was so tight at home and Mar√≠a was so far behind in school. 

With little support for her education, Mar√≠a began to lose hope. She felt fearful for her future.

But thanks to kind supporters like you, her story is just beginning to change. 

üìö Mar√≠a received a backpack filled with school supplies, which have made a world of difference. And her family began attending workshops on the importance of education and how they can better support their children‚Äôs studies at home. They‚Äôve also learned about health nutrition and hygiene, so they can nourish their children in body, mind, and spirit. 

What else has changed?
üéí Her mom started encouraging her education.
üçé The whole family began making healthier choices.
üåü And Mar√≠a? She‚Äôs thriving‚Äîmore engaged, more confident, and ready to shape her own future.

This World Hunger Day, we‚Äôre reminded that hunger takes many forms. Sometimes, it looks like a child without schoolbooks.

‚ú® But with your love beside them, families like Mar√≠a‚Äôs can break down these barriers and stop hunger from stealing their children‚Äôs hopes and dreams.

#WorldHungerDay #EducationForAll #EndChildHunger #SupportEducation #FoodForTheHungry

Hunger is... risking your safety just to earn enough to eat. 

Before she became a farmer, Sorn spent her days fishing in her community in Cambodia. This was exhausting, dangerous work that barely provided enough income for her family to survive. Without resources or training, agriculture felt out of reach.  

And like many others in her village, her children missed school and struggled with health issues tied to poor nutrition and limited access to care. 

But when she joined an agriculture program, everything began to change. With training, tools, and support, she learned how to grow vegetables and raise chickens sustainably without relying on harmful chemicals like her previous job had required. Now, she earns a stable income, supports her family, and leads her community as a key farmer. 

Her dream? To help more women become leaders in farming, and to make sure no child in her village must risk their future just to survive. 

With the support of compassionate people like you, whole communities, like Sorn‚Äòs can thrive and create lasting change for families and their children.  

#WorldHungerDay #HungerIs #EndHunger #FoodForTheHungry #Agriculture #Cambodia #FarmingForChange

Food for the Hungry‚Äôs Chief Development Officer, Juliana, recently met Annabelle in the Philippines. Annabelle leads an association of 25 members who are working together to harvest crops from a shared community field.

Thanks to your support of Food for the Hungry, they‚Äôre now growing high-value crops like peppers, squash, and eggplant‚Äîproviding sustainable income for their families. Because of this, Annabelle has been able to renovate her home and help cover her grandchildren‚Äôs education costs.

Thank you to everyone who has given to Food for the Hungry. Your generosity is making a lasting impact‚Äîfeeding children and families in some of the hardest places, while helping them grow mentally, physically, and spiritually as they flourish.

A mother and child in Vietnam, 1975‚Äîsharing a quiet moment of reading and connection.

#FoodForTheHungry #Mother #Parent #Reading #ThrowbackThursday #Vietnam

In Southeast Asia, the Philippines ranks second in the number of healthy years of life lost due to mental health issues among individuals aged 5‚Äì24. This shocking statistic shows the urgent need for accessible mental health support for Filipino adolescents.

In response, young Filipinos are taking steps to care for their mental health. With help from local groups like Phlourish Mental Health Initiative Inc., they are finding ways to get the support they need.

Food for the Hungry Philippines is working with these communities to connect them with helpful resources. Thanks to the support of donors like you, more young Filipinos can access the care they deserve.

#MentalHealthMatters #MentalHealth #Philippines #FoodForTheHungry #FHPhilippines

It‚Äôs amazing what can happen when a church community says ‚Äúyes‚Äù to serving others. Grace Church of Greater Akron recently visited their partner community in Guatemala.

During their trip, they offered medical care to 160 patients from the community and six surrounding areas. From general medicine to audiology, dental, and nutrition support.

One visiting midwife also trained eight local midwives on caring for high-risk pregnancies and practicing safe hygiene during labor and delivery. This knowledge will save lives for years to come.

With dedication and resilience, communities in Guatemala are building a healthier future, and we‚Äôre grateful for Grace Church‚Äôs commitment to walking with them every step of the way.

#FoodForTheHungry #ChurchPartners #Guatemala #FaithInAction

"My lost hope is now fulfilling one of my dreams." ‚Äî Ana Mar√≠a

In a small remote community, Ana Mar√≠a witnessed firsthand the struggles her neighbors faced. Some families were even forced to migrate to find better opportunities. As the primary caregiver for her grandchildren, she carried the responsibility of providing for her family, often with limited resources and little hope for change.

üíö Everything started to shift when Ana Mar√≠a joined a savings group. Through training in financial literacy and entrepreneurship, she learned the power of saving and investing. With support of her savings group and a new sewing machine, Ana Mar√≠a was able to grow her clothing business.

üëè Today, Ana Mar√≠a‚Äôs income has increased by 50%, enabling her family to enjoy more varied food and a better quality of life. She hopes to expand her business, open a workshop to teach others the art of sewing, and continue creating a future filled with opportunity ‚Äî not just for her family, but for her entire community.

Through your support, families like Ana Mar√≠a‚Äôs are building brighter futures, filled with hope, resilience, and new opportunities.

#FoodForTheHungry #SavingsGroup #WomenEmpowerment #Entrepreneurship #FHImpact

Today, we honor the many different ways families can look all around the world. Families are the foundation of our communities, nurturing resilience, fostering growth, and instilling values that go beyond generations.

Let's celebrate and support families everywhere, recognizing their crucial role in building a more compassionate and sustainable world.‚Äã

#FoodForTheHungry #InternationalDayOfFamilies #Family #Community #GlobalUnity

"I won‚Äôt lie, I cried tears of joy because I felt that my life was about to change." ‚Äî Mutamba, Rwanda 

At 19, Mutamba faced immense challenges‚Äîdropping out of school and turning to farming to support his grandmother. His determination led him to a vocational training program, where he pursued his dream of becoming a mechanic. 

After six months of training and receiving essential tools, he secured an internship. Today, at 21, Mutamba works at a garage, turning his aspirations into reality.‚Äã

Through your support, individuals like Mutamba are transforming their lives, gaining skills, and contributing positively to their communities.‚Äã

#FoodForTheHungry #FHImpact #Rwanda #Mechanic

üíê Celebrating Mothers Around the World üåç

This Mother's Day, we honor the strength, love, and resilience of mothers everywhere. From bustling cities to quiet villages, moms are the heart of every community.

ü©∑ In Bolivia, Mother's Day is commemorated on May 27th, honoring the women who fought for the country's independence, with schools organizing performances and children presenting handcrafted gifts.

üíú In Ethiopia, families gather for a three-day celebration called Antrosht, marking the end of the rainy season and honoring mothers with shared meals and storytelling.

üíõ In the Philippines, children express their love by preparing breakfast in bed, writing heartfelt letters, or presenting handmade gifts to their mothers.

At Food for the Hungry, we are privileged to work alongside incredible mothers who strive daily to provide for their families and build thriving communities. Their dedication inspires us, and with the support of donors like you, we can continue to support programs that empower these mothers and their families. 

This Mother's Day, let's celebrate and support mothers everywhere.

#MothersDay #GlobalMothers #FoodForTheHungry #CelebrateMoms

üåç From One Mother to Another: Share the Gift of Clean Water

This Mother's Day, make a meaningful impact by empowering another mother to provide clean and safe water for her family. By gifting clean water, you can honor your mother AND empower another to care for her family's health and future.‚Äã

Why Clean Water?

üíßHealthier Families: Less waterborne diseases.
üíßEducational Access: Children spend more time in school.‚Äã
üíßCommunity Development: Improved health and opportunities.‚Äã

This Mother's Day, make a meaningful difference by giving the gift of clean water in your mom's name.

www.fh.org/water

#FoodForTheHungry #MothersDay #CleanWater #EmpowerMoms #GiveBack #GlobalImpact

üêê Mother's Day Gift Idea: Honor the Original GOAT

This Mother's Day, celebrate your mom‚Äîthe original Greatest Of All Time‚Äîby empowering another mother to build a better future for her family. Through the gift of a goat, you provide a family with a sustainable source of nutrition, income, and agricultural support.‚Äã

Goats offer more than meets the eye:‚Äã

üêê Milk for nutrition
üêê Manure to fertilize crops
üêê Income through the sale of offspring and dairy products

Your thoughtful gift not only honors your mom's legacy but also equips another mom with the tools for her whole family to thrive.‚Äã

Go to fh.org/gifts

#FoodForTheHungry #MothersDay #OriginalGOAT #EmpowerMoms #GiveBack

Borann‚Äôs parents were going to have to pull her out of school. üíî 

Growing up in poverty in Cambodia meant every day was a struggle for Borann‚Äôs family to make ends meet. Her parents were on the verge of sending 10-year-old Borann to work to help her family survive. Borann knew that without education, there was no way she could reach her dream of becoming a teacher.  

Then someone caring like you helped change everything. 

Thanks to the love and kindness of a sponsor like you, Borann was able to stay in school. She gained the education and encouragement she desperately needed. And the leadership skills and confidence to reach for her dream. First, she mentored younger children. Then, Borann became a Literacy Program Teacher‚Äîhelping children in her community to learn to read and write their own futures. 

"Sponsorship gave me the courage to teach, grow, and believe in myself," says Borann. 

Borann‚Äôs story could have ended in struggle. Instead, it's full of hope and proof of how your love can help a child like Borann build the future God intends for them. Answer God‚Äôs call to sponsor a child like Borann today and help them transform their future. 

#FoodForTheHungry #ChildSponsorship #EducationForAll #HopeForTomorrow #SponsorshipChangesLives #FaithInAction

"I wish to see my students grow up to become future leaders who can take care of themselves,‚Äú says Komaa, a Ugandan primary school teacher.

Komaa is a dedicated primary school teacher in the Adjumani district of Uganda. Though her dedication had not wavered, she encountered a few obstacles that made it challenging to provide quality education to her students. Through your generous support, Komaa was able to receive training in early childhood development, child-friendly teaching methods, and financial literacy. These tools not only enhanced Komaa‚Äôs teaching and led to a promotion to deputy head, but also empowered her to uplift her community.‚Äã

Komaa's commitment extends beyond the classroom. By participating in village savings and loan associations, she improved her family's food security and inspired others to prioritize education.‚Äã 

On this National Teacher Day, we celebrate educators like Komaa, whose dedication and resilience illuminate the path to a brighter future. Her story shows the impact of investing in teachers. When educators thrive, communities flourish.‚Äã

#NationalTeacherDay #TeacherAppreciation #FHImpact #EducationMatters #Uganda #TeacherAppreciationDay #FoodFortheHungry #TeachersMatter

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre doing our best with what little we have. But our safety and the safety of our patients shouldn‚Äôt come down to chance,‚Äù says Dr. Habtie.

In Ebinat, Ethiopia, health workers confront daily challenges without proper protective equipment. But thanks to our generous supporters, the hospital was able to receive essential supplies. These supplies significantly reduced staff exposure and infection risk during patient evaluations, lab procedures, deliveries, and emergency care.‚Äã However, the reality remains stark. The gloves, intended to last four days for 20 staff members, were quickly depleted due to the large number of patients.

As the world recognizes World Hand Hygiene Day, Ebinat‚Äôs story reminds us that hand hygiene is not a privilege; it‚Äôs a right and a necessity for health care workers.

Fun fact: Guatemalan children celebrate Easter with colorful street carpets! üíöüíôüíõüß°

For children in Guatemala, Semana Santa ‚Äì Easter Holy Week ‚Äì includes fireworks, upbeat music, and colorful street-art carpets to pave the way for festive parades.

Children love helping their families cover the streets with alfombras (carpets) ‚Äî works of art using brightly colored sawdust, leaves, and flowers. They are soon trampled by the Easter procession marching over them ‚Äî a symbol of love and sacrifice. 

And like these alfombras, your kindness paves the way for children‚Äôs hearts to celebrate God‚Äôs love and goodness forever!

From Letters to Hugs: The Hall Family‚Äôs first visit with Adrian after 6 years of sponsorship. üåé

What started as simple letters blossomed into a life-changing connection that transcends borders and cultures. This unforgettable experience opened their eyes to the impact of Child Sponsorship‚Äîproving that love and support can truly transform lives. ‚ù§Ô∏è

Curious about sponsorship? Visit FH.org/sponsor to learn how you can change a life today.

‚ÄúSponsorship was my big, grand entry point to a better future.‚Äù ‚úùÔ∏è

Lery grew up in a fishing village in the Philippines, where life was tough. ‚ÄúA lot of people were really struggling in terms of food,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúEating three times a day or sending your kids to school wasn‚Äôt common.‚Äù But when someone loving like you chose to sponsor her, everything changed. 

Lery‚Äôs story will build your faith and remind you just how far your kindness can help a child go.

Together, we make a greater impact! üíö 

We‚Äôre grateful for the partnership between Awaken Church in Charleston, South Carolina, and FH Guatemala. Since 2023, Awaken Church has been walking alongside two communities in Guatemala.

On their most recent trip, the team supported the construction of more than 50 latrines and helped expand the local health clinic‚Äîefforts led by the community to create safer, healthier environments for children and their families. 

The teams also had the joy and honor of visiting several children who were sponsored by members of the team. It was an unforgettable highlight that reminded everyone of the deep, personal connections made possible through child sponsorship. 

We look forward to the journey ahead, walking alongside communities as they lead the way in creating hope, love, dignity, and lasting change.

#CommunityImpact #PartnershipForChange #HopeInAction #FHGuatemala #AwakenChurch #BringingHope #TogetherForGood #LastingChange #FoodfortheHungry #guatemalatrip

Can you imagine if all you had to feed your starving baby was water mixed with sugar?

For Gebrie, a mother in Ethiopia, that heartbreaking reality is all she had left to give her 8-month-old daughter, Ashine. Drought has taken their crops, their livestock, and their hope. Without food, children like Ashine will not survive.

Please put your faith into action to bring hope and life-saving help to a mother like Gebrie and a child like Ashine as a reflection of God‚Äôs life-saving love.

This Earth Day, we celebrate the power of renewable energy to transform lives and communities. 

Can you imagine trying to do your homework in the dark? For many children around the world, lack of electricity can have an impact on their schooling and studies. In response, communities are embracing solar energy to overcome these challenges.‚Äã  

With solar panel kits, families can illuminate their homes, enabling children to study after sunset and fostering safer, more productive environments.‚Äã This Earth Day, we honor the resilience and innovation of these communities as they harness the sun's power to build brighter futures.‚Äã

In coastal villages of Indonesia, locals prepare a traditional dish called Cacing Tembiluk, made from small marine worms harvested from nearby mangrove ecosystems. 

This unique delicacy can be enjoyed raw with salt and tamarind or cooked into a hearty meal, offering a flavorful taste of heritage and connection to the sea.

Let‚Äôs create a ripple effect of hope‚Äîstarting right now.

At Food for the Hungry, our mission to end all forms of human poverty starts with a heart to serve‚Äîboth around the world and right here at home in Phoenix, Arizona. üåµ

This week, our team rolled up our sleeves and packed food boxes at St. Mary's Food Bank, the world‚Äôs first food bank, serving Arizona families, seniors, and children since 1967.
